subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Aged Care

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Herron, representing the Minister for Aged Care. Can the minister confirm whether special or supported residential services will be fully exempt from the GST after 1 July?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I have a brief on that which states that the minister can say unequivocally that aged care will be GST free. This means that there will be no additional cost to residents for their aged care or accommodation either in the fees they pay for care services or in the accommodation bonds or charges they pay.
—That is the wrong brief again
—I am about 15 seconds into my answer and I have an interjection from Senator Evans, a young man who is trying to make his way with interjections.
—You didn't listen to the question. It's the wrong brief again.
—Order! The behaviour of those interjecting is disorderly.

—Accommodation bonds and charges are GST free. However, residents of aged care facilities will pay GST on additional discretionary services not covered by schedule 1, such as hairdressing or TV hire. That answers Senator Evans's interjection. If he would only wait, he would get an answer. Residents of extra service places will not pay GST on their extra service fees except for amounts that are for additional discretionary services, such as hairdressing and TV hire, as I have mentioned. Service providers will not be out of pocket. They will be able to register to claim refunds—called input tax credits—of the GST paid on their expenses including building, upgrading and all accommodation and care services. This means that all government funded services providing accommodation support and community care and who register for the GST will be able to claim input tax credits for any GST paid on their business costs. Providers will also benefit from the abolition of current indirect taxes, such as the wholesale sales tax and the fuel excise tax, which are currently embedded in their purchases.

answer.para: Aged and community care providers will have access to the government's $500 million package to assist small business and community organisations prepare for the introduction of the GST. Assistance is to be provided through a business skills education and information program on GST business skills, which amounts to $40 million; organisation delivered assistance supporting key industry and professional organisations in the delivery of information and assistance to their members and sectors, $130 million; an adviser education program to increase the number of people able to inform others on business skills and the GST, $7 million; direct assistance providing small and medium businesses and community organisations with redeemable certificates to be used in exchange for products or services to assist in the implementation of the GST, $320 million; and the GST Start-up Assistance Office running costs, $3 million.

Transactions involving the payment of subsidies under the Aged Care Act 1997 made by the Commonwealth to aged care providers will not be subject to the GST. This applies to subsidies paid for residential aged care subsidies, community aged care packages and flexible care subsidies. All community aged care services funded under the Home and Community Care Act 1985, the Aged Care Act 1997 or other Commonwealth or state funded programs will be GST free. This includes Meals on Wheels, home help, home maintenance, gardening, transport, respite and social support services such as day care centres, personal and nursing care and community care packages. In addition, privately funded community care services involving the supply of nursing and personal care will be GST free. This ensures that older people and people with disabilities who purchase these services privately will also obtain them GST free. The government is maintaining its commitment to ensure that pensioners and non-pensioners will be fully and permanently protected from fee increases to the four per cent GST pension increase. We have heard nothing from the Labor Party as to what their policy is because they are keeping the GST. There is no unequivocal statement that they are not. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I was asking about the GST treatment of special or supported residential services, not hostels and nursing homes. I want to know from the minister: are special or supported residential services, from what he has been telling us, going to be treated the same way as residents of hostels, who are entirely free from the GST? Can he confirm that it will be up to providers to determine how much of the fee they pay is related to care and will be GST free and how much is related to accommodation?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —Obviously a detailed answer is required for some of those questions. I am happy to take the matter to the minister and provide the senator with an answer. They are details which are not in the brief. I would be the last to answer incorrectly to the Senate, and I am giving an honest and correct answer. It is not in the brief. I will have to get back to the honourable senator with an answer from the minister.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, Senator Alston. Will the minister inform the Senate how long-overdue tax reform, including $12 billion in personal income tax cuts, will benefit small business and improve the living standards of all Australians? Is the minister aware of any alternative policy approaches for the small business sector, and what would be the impact if these were implemented?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Yes, $12 billion, Senator Calvert, is just for starters because there is a great deal that can be done for the small business community, if you are committed to helping them. In other words, the substantial reform of the tax system—which will remove provisional tax, which will remove wholesale sales tax, which will remove stamp duty in a whole range of areas and transactions—in addition to the prescribed payments system, the halving of the capital gains tax rate, the preferential treatment of assets that have been held for 15 years or more and the reform and simplification of depreciation are all critical issues for the small business community, and quite rightly so because they constitute about 50 per cent of the employment in the Australian work force.

answer.para: Madam President, you would have thought that all the major parties would be interested in helping small business, wouldn't you? I suppose the only one who ever tried was Senator Schacht. His idea of helping the small business sector was to reduce the large businesses. Apart from that, all we have ever really had is a Labor Party that has never had a small business minister in cabinet. In fact, it did not even have a small business minister for about five years. I am not sure who in the Senate from the Labor Party represents the public transport union, but I am sure he will get back to it on this. The secretary of that union said recently, `How many small business people stood on polling booths or letterboxed for the ALP in the last state election campaign?' That is really what it is all about, as far as they are concerned.

So I did have a look at the ALP web site to see exactly what those opposite have in mind for small business. Well, it is fascinating. You do not actually find any policy documents there. What you find is that the ALP is currently reviewing its policy—and, `As policy positions are refined, they will be published here.' So, in other words, in due course we might get some policy refinements. But what we have got to date listed here are six policy position/discussion papers on things like Family Futures, APEC: Meeting The Challenge Of The New Millennium—I am sure that will go down well in mainstream Australia and the small business sector!—and Framework for an Australian Coastguard. These are the sorts of priorities that Labor is interested in.

talk.start.para: —It's a shame they weren't when they were in government.

—Of course, they showed not the slightest interest in any of this. So, Madam President, where does small business rate? It rates nowhere, as far as the Labor Party is concerned. If you look at where jobs growth is, it is overwhelmingly in the small business sector. The latest ABS statistics, for example, showed that there were 17,500 new communications jobs in Australia last year. Morgan and Banks say that 65 per cent of Australia's IT companies plan to take on additional staff—and, again, they are overwhelmingly small business.

answer.para: So what is the Labor Party's view of the next 10 years? You have heard that two-word slogan/policy called the Knowledge Nation. What is the ALP's view of where the jobs growth is going to come from? You look at something quaintly called Workforce 2010. What you find there is that what Labor is in favour of is a lift in the number of apprentices and trainees in traditional service areas—meaning higher union membership—like sales, marketing, retail and hospitality. But what happens when it comes to IT&T? It does not even rate a mention in the jobs growth by occupation.

Labor predict that there will be a decline in communication services of 50,000 jobs. We know that they do not have a shadow minister for IT. It is an appalling disgrace, and I can understand why Senator Lundy is very put out about that. But they are not alone; they do not have a minister for IT in Victoria either under a Labor government. But it really is a devastating indictment of the attitude of Labor to the small business sector if they not only do not have a policy document, if they do not have a minister in cabinet and now they are predicting a jobs decline in the very area where small business is likely to deliver jobs growth. (Time expired)

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources.
—Jeannie! Jeannie—

—Thank you, Madam President. My question is directed to the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. With the introduction of the new tax system and the $12 billion worth of personal income tax cuts just 10 days away, will the minister outline the benefits of tax reform for both the Australian car industry and car buyers?

talker.name: Minchin, Sen Nick
Senator MINCHIN
talker.role: Minister for Industry, Science and Resources

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Chapman for that very good question. The car industry and car buyers are looking forward very much to 1 July because that is the day when Labor's absolutely hopeless wholesale sales tax system will be consigned to the dustbin of history. Gone will be the day when the car industry, more than any other, pays the burden of Labor's wholesale sales tax. It is an indictment of Labor that nearly one quarter of the revenue from the wholesale sales tax comes from just one product—the car industry. Under the new tax system the car industry will contribute just three per cent of GST revenue compared to the nearly 25 per cent currently contributed by the car industry under the wholesale sales tax. That will mean a reduction in the tax on an average car, as this Senate well knows, of $2,000, and the industry's export efforts will be considerably enhanced by taking off the load of imbedded taxes on our exports, which should mean the industry can improve on the record export performance last year of $3.2 billion.

answer.para: The industry itself is predicting very strong growth under the new tax system. Just last week the President of Ford Australia, Geoff Polites, predicted that July 2000, just a couple of weeks away, will be the best sales month ever for the car industry in Australia's history. He was not just talking about the best sales month for July; he was talking about the best month ever in this industry's history. He predicts that demand will stay strong for the rest of the year 2000 and then increase over the next three years to the point where car sales in this country will total one million vehicles, which will be a leap in sales of a quarter of a million, nearly a third, compared to the current three-quarters of a million in sales. The industry itself supports Mr Polites' forecast.

The industry are quite correct in being so optimistic. They have a very strong policy base to work from. We have a policy framework that has delivered the longest period of strong economic growth in 30 years and has delivered car buyers a low interest rate environment and is delivering a tax reform package to help the industry even more. Compare that to what we get from the opposition. This opposition voted against cutting the tax on cars by $2,000. They have had nothing positive to say about this industry for more than a year. All Mr McMullan, the relevant shadow minister, has done is talk down the industry repeatedly. He predicted massive job losses in car dealers. He predicted thousands of stand downs in the car manufacturing industry. He predicted more industry downturns. And he has been wrong on every count. It seems that the Labor Party have been secretly hoping that this industry would fall flat on its face in the lead-up to the introduction of the GST, and it simply has not happened. Under our opponents, the Labor Party, the industry languished—its sales were static, going nowhere. This industry has had its best three years ever under four years of coalition government. The best years for this industry await it under the new tax system.

talk.start.para: —That is not true. That is an outright untruth. That is just not true.
—Senator Cook, you are shouting.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Boarding Houses

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services. Is the minister aware that the Treasurer in a statement last night attempted to argue that the negative short-term effects of the GST would be offset by overall growth and competitive supply pressures in the boarding house sector? Can the minister responsible for housing policy confirm that there has been a continued decline of boarding house stock in Australia over a sustained period of time? Given this fact, how can the Treasurer claim that boarding house residents will ever be back in the black?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minster for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Yes, certainly I have responsibility at the federal level for the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, which is administered by the states. I also have responsibility at the federal level for rent assistance, which is the assistance for accommodation used by the majority of people on low incomes in Australia. Many more people live in private rentals than live in public housing. The senator may not be aware of the fact that since I became the minister in 1996 I have spent a great deal of time and effort in trying to encourage community organisations and state governments to pay more attention to the value of community housing which, for many of the people who are in hostels and boarding houses, would be a more caring environment than many of the hostels and boarding houses in which they currently live.

answer.para: I would have hoped that when we came into government we would have inherited a very vibrant community housing sector, as is found in Britain and in Europe, for example. It is my wish and dream that Australia will encourage greater numbers of people who are currently living in hostels and boarding houses to be better housed in community housing where they are not only getting a roof but also getting the services they need. For example, many people have mental illness and to leave them simply with a roof over their head that may or may not be adequate is not good enough. This has been a real effort on my behalf since I came into this job. It is true to say that boarding houses come and go and some are excellent and some are not so excellent, but what we believe we have done in terms of the GST is introduce an equitable system which will be fair to everybody.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Is the minister aware that the private group providing some 80 per cent of the boarding house accommodation in Sydney's inner west—that is, In-West Holdings Pty Ltd—has today announced that it is withdrawing from the provision of boarding house accommodation? Doesn't this action disprove the Treasurer's assertion of last night, as well as throw over 300 people onto the streets and into the short-term housing market where the effects of the GST will harm them further?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minster for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —It is obvious that the senator has not thought this through. The Olympic Games are coming to New South Wales. The state government have been very keen to make sure that the Olympic Games is the highlight of their political careers and they have had a long warning time to make sure that people in Sydney are not treated as they have been in some previous games where they have been marginalised and left without homes at all. So the New South Wales Labor government have had plenty of opportunity to monitor what is happening in an area which is their direct responsibility; hostels and boarding houses are not the Commonwealth's direct responsibility. I would have though that Mr Knight, Mr Carr and Mr Egan would have been putting their best foot forward for several years now to see that better housing for people currently living in boarding houses and hostels was provided. If they had been enthusiastic supporters of community housing, we might not be facing this now. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Caravan Parks and Boarding Houses

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Is the minister aware of the many requests made by the Democrats since June last year for specific data relating to the price effects of the changes on caravan parks and boarding house residents?
—Senators on my left are in breach of the standing orders. It is important that I am able to hear the question.
—Senator Ray, I am speaking. I need to hear the question.

—Can the minister explain why these requests were ignored? And can the minister explain why the modelling on boarding houses was not released to us as promised but was released nationally on Channel 9 last night?
—Order! We will wait, Senator.

—This is an issue they apparently care about, but the noise is distracting. This modelling was released last night by Laurie Oakes on Channel 9. Can the minister explain how and why figures in Mr Oakes's version of the report—apparently finished in January this year—have been changed in Econtech's supposedly final report, dated March 2000?

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —There a number of aspects to Senator Lees's question. Senator Lees was keen to know why she had not received the report earlier from the Treasurer. I will make inquiries of the Treasurer. The Treasurer, as you know, Senator Lees, is always helpful. I will check the points that you have made with him. As far as Laurie Oakes is concerned, Madam President, I am not precisely sure of the source of the data used by Mr Oakes. That is probably a matter for Mr Oakes to deal with.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There are persistent interjections on my left.

—Senator Lees, it seems to me that you would be pleased, however, with Econtech's final report, which provides independent support for the government's decision to allow suppliers of long-term commercial accommodation a choice of taxation treatment. Allowing boarding house operators to choose the taxation treatment will result in the lowest price increase for residents. Boarding house operators, as Senator Lees would know, can choose a taxation treatment and switch later if the alterative treatment will result in a lower price rise.

answer.para: This report shows that, in the short run, boarding house residents are likely to experience a similar price rise, regardless of the choice of taxation by a boarding house operator. The Econtech estimate is that, in the short run, boarding house rents under concessional GST treatment would rise by four per cent, while under the input tax treatment they would rise by 3.6 per cent. Given that these are only indicative figures subject to the usual modelling assumptions, these results can only be viewed as broadly comparable. Importantly, the Econtech report shows that in the long run—and I think this is very important, Senator Lees, and I think this will answer your question—people who are charged a concessional rate of GST on their boarding house rent will face a lower price rise than boarding house residents who are input taxed. Under the concessional GST treatment the rise is 1.5 per cent compared with the estimated increase of 3.1 per cent under input taxing. Thus, Madam President, if the boarding house owner chooses to apply the concessional rate of GST, residents will see their rents rise by about one half of the increase if input taxation is chosen.

By providing a choice between concessional GST treatment and input taxation, the government is protecting, I believe, those on low incomes from a price rise in rental costs associated with the GST. I think it is also important to note—and Senator Lees would know this as well as anyone in this chamber—that the government is also providing a generous compensation package to those people on low incomes to cover the costs of the GST. The package includes increasing the maximum rate of rental assistance by seven per cent to compensate people on low incomes for rises in rental costs, increasing pensions and allowances by four per cent to compensate low income people for other expected price increases, and of course income tax cuts and increases in family benefits will also benefit many residents of long-term commercial accommodation.

talk.start.para: —By way of a supplementary question, Minister, even the edited version—the one you have laundered—is not satisfactory. The long term is about eight to 10 years, and I do not believe these people should be asked to wait that long. I remind you that it was we who asked for this modelling and that this is unfinished business. Specifically, I ask the minister: why was Mr Oakes able to obtain this report, while our letters, faxes and phone calls to several departments went unanswered? Where is the caravan park modelling? Will the minister undertake to tell us, if he does not have it with him today, when we can pop upstairs to Mr Oakes's office and get that one?

Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

But you are dealing with a serious aspect, in particular the claim that it would take between five and 10 years for the long-run price effects to flow through. According to the advice that I have received, that is nonsense.

—The long-run price forecaster will start to flow through when boarding houses are partially refurbished or renovated or when new entrants enter the market.

—My question is to Senator Newman, the Minister for Family and Community Services. In light of recent reports that the government is seeking to contract out case management of the unemployed, will the minister categorically rule out any move by the government to transfer any of the existing responsibilities or services of Centrelink to private contractors?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN

Senator NEWMAN

talk.start.para: —The senator for the CPSU obviously had a speech to make on behalf of her constituents, regardless of the facts. —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer. As you will be aware, after the last election some $33 million was disbursed in public funding to political parties, and as a consideration for supply we can expect this will be reduced by $3 million at the next election under the GST. talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator KEMP
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —Let me make a couple of observations. I will check on the facts of what you have said, Senator. I think that is always wise, not that one does not trust Senator Brown. But I think that a number of us have noted, from long experience in this chamber, it probably is always wise to check on source material. I am a cautious person so I will certainly check on that. Where there is a registered body an input tax credit is claimed in those cases, so I am not quite sure what the general, overall thrust is of the problem you see. Out of courtesy to Senator Brown I will check very carefully what he has asserted to the Senate. Senator Brown, I will get back to you.

—Is the Minister for Family and Community Services aware that, according to a report released earlier this month by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, there are now 66,100 children prevented from accessing child care because of the cost pressures, an increase of 23,600 since 1996? Is the minister also aware that the percentage of children excluded from care because of the expense has doubled since this government was elected from 16 per cent to 32 per cent? Isn't this further proof that the government's spending cuts make child care harder to afford, pushing lower income families out of the system?
—Absolute rubbish.

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minster for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —Senator Patterson behind me, who knows a lot about these matters herself, is saying `rubbish' to the opposition's claims, and rubbish they are. Absolutely right, Senator. This government has spent more in every year of the four years that we have been in government on child care than was spent by the Labor Party in the last four years it was in government. The last four years we have been in government we have spent over $4 billion on child care. There have been more child-care centres established and more child-care places available than ever before.

answer.para: What is happening in the child-care area, of course, is that mothers are joining the work force increasingly. There are more sole parents in the work force than there have been for some years. Many families are changing their child care arrangements with the opportunities for family friendly workplaces. They are tending to change the way they use child care. The assistance is there, as I have told the Senate before. Parents on low incomes with two children in long day child care are getting a subsidy from the Australian taxpayer of about $12,500 a year, and families with moderate incomes with two children in child care are getting subsidies of about $10,300 a year. Come 1 July these families will be getting increasing amounts of assistance, which will make child care more affordable than it has been for some time.

The interesting thing is that we have had a constant stream of misinformation being put about to the media and to families by our opposition. It is very unfair that the Labor Party has tried to portray child care as being unaffordable. When you take in the amount of the subsidies that the Australian taxpayers are paying now to assist families with child care it is pretty unrealistic of the opposition to try to frighten parents out of using child care at all. But what we are finding is that parents are using child care in different ways. We have got a very good quality child-care system in Australia. Everybody has an interest in having a quality assurance system, and this is what we inherited and what we have built on. Parents and people in the child-care industry should be appreciative of the fact that Australia stands so high in its quality of child care. Only the week before last in New York at a major forum associated with the special session of the General Assembly on women's affairs Australia was hailed for the work it has done and the achievements it has made in terms of child care and domestic violence. I, as the minister for Australia, was very proud to sit there and hear people from outside Australia making claims about it.

talk.start.para: —What did Natasha say? You were not proud of Natasha.
—On the other hand, Senator Stott Despoja managed to go to New York and bag her country from afar, to our great shame.
—You are joking, Minister. Are you honestly suggesting—

Senator NEWMAN

—Senator Alston suggests that Senator McKiernan is perhaps too old to help. —My question is to the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Newman. Minister, the government has worked hard to strengthen relations with other countries in our region. Would you advise the Senate of developments in the social policy area that strengthen relations with our regional neighbours?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Minster for Family and Community Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —I am glad to see Senator Brandis, as a new senator for Queensland, focusing on important meetings which take place in his state. Our government has worked hard to strengthen relations in the region, and our leadership role in restoring peace to East Timor, for example, was lauded around the world. Another development, however, that has received little attention occurred last week—

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It is clear the opposition is not interested in the region or in good social policy development. Another development that received little attention occurred last week during the first ever Asia Social Policy Ministers Forum which was held in Brisbane, in Senator Brandis's home state. That was a historic and significant event that it seems will now be the first of regular forums of this type in the future. I am delighted to inform the Senate that ministers and their delegates moved last Friday to recommend ongoing forums to discuss major social policy developments that are vital to regional stability. At the forum there were representatives from China, Indonesia, Malaysia, New Zealand, Singapore and Thailand. All were enthusiastic about future ongoing forums, and there is great optimism that the success of the inaugural forum will encourage other Asian nations to participate.

answer.para: The discussions at the forum reinforced the common interests that Australia shares with the nations that participated. Ageing populations, the drift of population from country to city and changes to traditional family structures are all placing pressure on social security systems around our region. Responses to these challenges will be varied, of course, according to each country's own circumstances, but what is certain is that no country can afford to ignore the slow but steady demographic and social changes in the interests of stability in their own country as well as regional security. Ministers and delegates from the world's most populous nation, China, and the fourth most populous, Indonesia, expressed great concern at the social challenge caused by the depopulation of traditional rural areas and the drift to cities where unemployment and social unrest are growing. China, a country with 800 million people living in rural areas and an economy undergoing great change, faces a challenge that we in Australia could hardly begin to fathom.

Social security means regional security. It is a fact that participants at the forum are well aware of. Interestingly, Professor Stephen Fitzgerald, the Chairman of the Asia Australia Institute and a former ambassador to China, confirmed this when he addressed the forum participants on the importance of such meetings to healthy regional ties. As we work towards the reform of our welfare system, it makes sense to cement our ties with regional neighbours, each learning from the others how we respond to common challenges. This was a significant meeting. I am very disappointed, in fact, that it has been given very little attention when it is something of such long-term importance to Australia's wellbeing and to the wellbeing of the region.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Caravan Parks

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Family and Community Services (Senator Newman), to a question without notice asked by Senator Evans today, relating to the goods and services tax and long-term residents of caravan parks.

speech.para: What happened today is that the minister refused to repudiate Senator Ross Lightfoot's comments made yesterday about the GST impact on caravan park residents. What the minister is doing is endorsing those remarks. When asked about this issue yesterday, Senator Lightfoot said:

quote.para: These people are lucky. They are no more special than anyone else. It might be an incentive for them to get houses.

speech.para: That was Senator Lightfoot's depth of understanding of the issue; that was the government's degree of empathy for the position of caravan park residents, who will be the only group faced with a 5½ per cent GST on their rent. That is the level of understanding, empathy and support for people in caravan parks that this government has. Senator Ross Lightfoot is occasionally one out in the Liberal Party. He is occasionally regarded as a bit of a character, as sometimes running against the current orthodoxy of Liberal Party views. But on this occasion, Senator Ross Lightfoot and the Liberal Party are as one. They have that view of people who live in caravan parks; that is, if they do not like it, if they think there are going to get poorer as a result of having to pay tax on their caravan park rents, that will give them an incentive to go and buy houses. What a complete lack of understanding! Senator Ross Lightfoot is the Marie Antoinette of the Liberal government. She said, `Let them eat cake.' He said, `Let them go out and buy houses.'

They have no understanding that the majority of people living permanently in caravan parks are on low incomes, they have no understanding that the majority of people who live in caravan parks and boarding houses are in fact on pensions or social security payments, and they have no understanding that most people who live in caravan parks live there because they cannot afford houses. They live there because they make a choice to do so and because, in their economic circumstances, that is the best option for them. Many of them do not have the ability to buy a house, many of them do not have the sorts of options that Senator Lightfoot, from a very privileged background, has. They do not have the sort of superannuation he got from the state parliament to make those sorts of decisions. They live from hand to mouth and they struggle to make ends meet. Many of them are among the battlers of our society, and they live there because they have to—because Sydney land prices or the availability of housing in the various areas of Australia mean that other options are closed off to them. They live there out of the necessity. It is highly contemptuous of Senator Lightfoot and the minister to refuse to show some empathy for these people and to treat them with the disdain and the French aristocracy's view of the world that Senator Lightfoot expresses. These people are going to be made poorer by being the only group who are forced to pay a GST on their rents. These people are already struggling and doing it tough; they will be made to do it tougher under one of the unfairest aspects of a very unfair GST.

It is staggering that Senator Lightfoot does not have more appreciation of the issues and that the minister does not have either. Senator Lightfoot might like to go out to Mount Magnet, to Leonora, to Wiluna, to Meekatharra and to other places in the outback of Western Australia where large numbers of people live in caravan parks and boarding houses—as other Western Australian senators would know—who are forced, because of the lack of permanent accommodation and housing options, to live in caravan parks and boarding house arrangements. Those people will have no sympathy for Senator Lightfoot's views. In fact, I am sure that they will want to know what the member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Haase, has to say about their plight. There are thousands in my own state of Western Australia living in boarding houses and caravan parks who will not at all appreciate the tenor of these remarks and the government's complete lack of sympathy for their situation. As I understand it, there are more than 80,000 of these people living in boarding houses and caravan parks in New South Wales alone.

I want to mention boarding houses because most of the people living in boarding houses are in fact on the disability support pension. Many of them are people with severe disabilities. These are the people who are doing it toughest in our society, who lack opportunity and support and who are struggling to make ends meet on social security payments, but they are the only ones who are going to be forced to pay the 5½ per cent tax on their rent. They are being singled out. They are being treated very harshly. The government will not show any sympathy, any empathy or any support for their plight. The National Party have proved themselves to be totally ineffective as representatives, and Senator Lightfoot today represented the government's real view about these people. They do not care about them. The coalition do not care about the circumstances of these people. They see this as an incentive for them to buy houses. (Time expired)

talker.name: Patterson, Sen Kay
Senator PATTERSON
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Foreign Affairs

talk.start.para: —Day after day, the Labor Party decide they are going to have one scare campaign after the other. We can predict this. The Australian public can expect that, for the next 13 days until the GST is implemented, there will be a scare a day, as we had today in one of the questions about the implementation of the GST and the start-up cost. They never talk about the wholesale sales tax cost and what it cost in High Court charges. They never talk about whether or not you would have wholesale sales tax on cotton wool buds, frozen yoghurt or swimming pools. They never talk about all the anomalies that happened under Labor, all the increased costs with the implementation of their ramshackle wholesale sales tax system. All they can do is carp, complain and scare people. They did it with nursing homes when we had a policy about nursing homes. They do it all the time. They skate on the circumference of truth. They often tell untruths about our policies, and they do it again here today.
—They do it all the time.

—Yes, you are right, Senator Chapman, they do it all the time. It is one of the largest tax reforms in Australia's history. We are putting in place tax reform to ensure that we have finances without having to borrow as Labor did. Labor borrowed $10 billion from the next generation in their last year to pay for their splurges. We are actually putting in place a tax reform system which will enable us to have finances and the states to have the finances to pay for schools, roads and hospitals. Our tax base was shrinking, and we have done what was needed. We have had the guts to bring in a reform that will be good for all Australians and provide us with income into the future.

speech.para: The Labor Party comes in here every day with yet another scare tactic. It has never been the intention of the government that long-term residents of caravan parks or other forms of commercial accommodation like boarding houses should suffer any disadvantage. The operators of commercial residential premises—that is, caravan parks, camping grounds, hotels, motels, hostels, boarding houses and other premises—will have the option of not charging GST on services supplied but will not be entitled to input tax credits. They are the normal input taxation rules that apply to other rental accommodation. Alternatively, they can charge GST on 50 per cent of the price of the long-term accommodation and they will then be able to claim input tax credits.

I had a discussion this morning with some colleagues who have people who live in caravan parks in their electorates. They have had some concerned people come to them but, when they have had them come into their offices and explained to them what is going to happen, the people go away understanding the system and understanding that they are being treated fairly compared with other people. We constantly have Labor Party people telling absolute untruths about what is going to happen. The operators of commercial residential premises will have the option of choosing the tax treatment that serves them and their residents best. This should result in rents being lower than they would have been if there had been no choice available. Long-term residents of commercial accommodation, such as caravan parks and boarding houses, will also benefit from the compensation measures included in the tax reform package. We never ever hear the Labor Party in this chamber talk about this. Not once has one member on the other side got up and talked about the whole tax package. They talk about only one side of it. They do not talk about the compensation. They do not talk about the seven per cent increase in rent assistance to enable people to cope with the rise in rental costs. Additionally, they do not say that pensions will increase by four per cent to deal with the inflationary effect of the GST.

talk.start.para: —How much will inflation increase?
—The pensions and benefits will stay two per cent ahead of that inflationary rise.
—Let's see!

—That is another tactic. `Let's see,' they say. We will have taxation relief for people living in caravan parks. People who have incomes will have taxation relief. But we do not hear them talk about that. When they had a tax policy in 1993 it was `l-a-w law tax cuts'. They went to the 1993 election and told the Australian people they were going to have tax cuts. What did they do? They came in afterwards and said that they were not going to do it. Many older people live in caravan parks. They said all pensions would be taken out of the tax system. Two days after the 1993 election they came out and said, `Sorry, that was an error in our policy. We didn't mean to say that.' That is the sort of treatment older people got under Labor. (Time expired)
—Senator Patterson has finished. I thought she had finished when she sat down.

—That is very decent of you, Senator Patterson. It is unfortunate that you did not use your five minutes of debating time—and I never interjected once—to speak to the motion in front of the chamber at the moment, which of course was moved by Senator Evans and asks that the Senate take note of the response from Minister Newman to his question about your coalition colleague—
—Address the chair, please, Senator McKiernan.

—About Senator Patterson's coalition colleague, Senator Ross Lightfoot, senator for Western Australia. He is Senator Boswell's coalition colleague as well. Senator Lightfoot had this to say yesterday on the matter of the GST and its impact on people who choose—some choose wilfully and some do not have the choice—to live in caravan parks. Senator Lightfoot said:

quote.para: These people are lucky. They are no more special than anyone else. It might be an incentive for them to get houses.

speech.para: How insensitive can you get! I am sure that when Senator Boswell gets up here to defend his coalition colleague he will distance himself from the insensitivity of Senator Lightfoot—or perhaps he will not. All too often in this chamber Senator Lightfoot goes out on the public stage and makes outrageous and sometimes even racist statements and nobody on that side of the chamber distances themselves from what Senator Lightfoot has to say.

How many of them came into this chamber at the first opportunity after Senator Lightfoot made his statements about the white Zimbabwean farmers coming into Australia and when he was questioned about what would happen to the black workers of those white Zimbabwean farmers, who were also being attacked, who were also being maimed, who were also being mutilated and whose families were also being threatened? `There is going to be no room in Australia for the black ones.' Did any of his coalition colleagues come in here and defend him or repudiate his statements or even distance themselves from what Senator Lightfoot had to say? No.

Earlier in the year, the good coalition senator from Western Australia put out a media release headed `Worried about your wife and children? Go home and check!' This was about illegal immigrants coming into the country. Senator Lightfoot's media statement had this to say:

quote.para: Despite his strong support for the introduction of a limited three year visa, Senator Lightfoot has variously described the illegal arrivals as queue-jumpers, criminals and law-breakers as well as possible carriers of communicable disease. He makes it clear that he would prefer to see the immigrants returned to their last port of embarkation.

speech.para: It goes on to quote Senator Lightfoot as saying:

quote.para: ... we simply cannot become the refuge for all of the world's troubled, dispossessed or religious zealots, who see Australia as a natural haven.

speech.para: Further on, he has something to say about the prejudice and intolerance that they bring in with them. If there is anybody in this particular chamber—and my colleague Senator Eggleston would know this—who knows anything about prejudice and intolerance, it is our good colleague Senator Lightfoot from Western Australia. He knows all about it and, indeed, we have witnessed some of his comments in this place in the past. Very shortly after he arrived here, he had some words to say about Aboriginals in this place.

talk.start.para: —When are you going to start playing the ball, not the man?
—What about the GST? That's what we're talking about.
—What about about this statement? See if Senator Eggleston will distance himself from this statement. Senator Calvert, will you distance yourself from your coalition colleague for making this remark:

quote.para: These people are lucky. They are no more special than anyone else. It might be an incentive for them to get houses.

speech.para: Do you, Senator Calvert, agree with those remarks? Does Senator Eggleston agree with those remarks? Does Senator Boswell agree with his coalition colleague? Is he indeed speaking on behalf of the coalition when he makes these very insensitive remarks that show no understanding? (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Whatever the intent of Senator Lightfoot's remarks, the fact remains that under the coalition government housing has become far more affordable. It has become far more affordable because the coalition has managed the economy better. Interest rates are lower and, after the new tax system is introduced on 1 July, most people in Australia will be paying only 30 cents in the dollar as tax, and they will have a higher disposable income and more money to spend on mortgages. So more Australians will be getting into housing and buying their own house.
—What about interest rates?

—Interest rates are nowhere near the levels they reached at the height of the totally irresponsible and utterly bad administration of the Hawke and Keating governments. Interest rates under the Howard government have been at record lows. Right now, they are slowly going up, but they are miles away from the horrific rates they reached in the late eighties under the Hawke-Keating regime. That is something which I am sure the Labor Party does not like being reminded of, but it is something that I assure you the people of Australia will never forget. They will never forget that the Labor Party is a party of inept and incompetent economic managers.

speech.para: The new tax system that we are bringing in means that most Australians are better off in a general way. While the Labor Party, as Senator Patterson said, are picking an issue a day on the tax system—something to attack the government with as we count down, with 10½ days to go—it is my bet that, once the tax system is introduced and the new system is in place, we will not hear a word from the Labor Party, because they know the benefits to the Australian population will be so good. The Labor Party strategically know they have to go in and try to score a few points now because they sure are not going to score any after 1 July. They will find that the Australian people will like the $12 billion in tax cuts, they will like the fact that most people will be paying only 30 cents in the dollar, they will like the fact that wholesale sales taxes will go and they will like the fact that almost all consumer goods in the shops will be cheaper and that cars will be cheaper, and they will find that it is really nice to have the extra money to buy the cheaper consumer goods.

talk.start.para: —They know that's not true, as well!

—Senator Carr, if you think that, you are sadly mistaken. They know it is going to be good for them. Let us look at the question of taxation on caravans in caravan parks. quote.para: NEW BUSINESS TAX SYSTEM (INTEGRITY MEASURES) BILL 2000

The New Business Tax System (Integrity Measures) Bill 2000 contains two important integrity measures. The Review of Business Taxation, chaired by John Ralph, AO, recommended the measures and the Government announced on 11 November 1999 that it would adopt them.
The measures will:
limit the extent to which taxpayers can use non-commercial losses to reduce the tax paid on their other income; and
require that prepayments for services under tax shelter arrangements be deducted over the period during which the services are provided, rather than being immediately tax deductible.

The non-commercial losses measure will improve the integrity of the tax system by limiting the extent to which losses from an individual's non-commercial business activities are used to reduce the tax paid on other income such as salary or wage income. The Ralph Review of Business Taxation noted that there was a significant revenue leakage from unprofitable activities carried out by taxpayers and that many of these activities are more like hobbies and/or lifestyle choices.

The Review recommended, and the Government accepted, that it was necessary to implement a systemic solution to this issue rather than continue to rely on the current law which is resource intensive to administer.

The new rules I am introducing today do not change the existing general law tests that determine whether an individual is carrying on a business activity; nor do they deny the deductibility of a loss from that activity.

The rules ensure that individual taxpayers carrying on a business activity either alone or in partnership may only claim a loss from that activity against their other income in an income year if they satisfy one of five tests in that year.

The tests look at the activity's level of turnover, history of profitability, the value of real property used in carrying on the business and the value of other assets used in carrying on the business. Only one of the tests needs to be passed to enable an individual's loss from a business activity in a year to be deducted against the individual's other assessable income, such as wages and salary.
There is also a discretion to allow the losses where the business is affected by special circumstances, such as natural disasters, or is in its start-up phase.

In addition, if an individual is carrying on a primary production business, the measure does not apply where their non primary production assessable income (excluding net capital gains) is less than $40,000. This assists those small primary producers who find it necessary to support themselves through moderate amounts of off-farm income (particularly during periods of hardship), while genuinely, at the same time, seeking to pursue their farm activities on a commercial basis.
Where a test is not satisfied in an income year, the loss is deferred and can be offset in a future year against income from the activity or against other income if one of the tests is satisfied.
These rules will apply to assessments for the 2000-01 income year and later income years.
The estimated increases in revenue from the measure are $30 million in the 2000-2001 financial year, $230 million in 2001-2002 and $170 million in 2002-2003.
The second measure in the bill deals with prepayments. Again this integrity measure is based on the recommendations of the Ralph Review of Business Taxation.

The measure introduces new rules on when prepaid expenditure for services in respect of `tax shelter' arrangements is to be deductible. The effect is to align the deduction for the expenditure with the period during which the services are provided rather than being immediately deductible when the payment is made.

Under the existing law, prepayments for things to be done wholly within 13 months, including those relating to tax shelter arrangements, are immediately deductible for small business taxpayers and for payments outside a business. This rule has given rise to many tax minimisation schemes, particularly end-of-year schemes.

These new rules will reduce the tax advantages that are derived from participation in these tax shelters by limiting immediate deductibility for prepayments. This measure will promote equity in the tax system and more productive investment activity.
The new rules will apply to prepaid expenditure incurred by all taxpayers under tax shelter arrangements after 1 p.m. Australian Eastern Summer Time on 11 November 1999.
However, certain prepayments will be specifically excluded from the operation of the new rules. These include prepayments for:
interest on borrowings to acquire real property or interests in real property, publicly listed shares or units in widely held unit trusts;
premiums for building, contents or rent protection insurance;
interest on infrastructure bonds;
irrevocable commitments entered into before 11 November 1999; and
arrangements which have an ATO product ruling, where the ruling issued or the application had been lodged with the ATO before 11 November 1999.
The estimated increases in revenue from the measure are $40 million in the 2000-2001 financial year, $100 million in 2001-2002 and $90 million in 2002-2003.
Full details of the measures in this bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum.
I commend the bill.
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 6) 2000

This bill amends the income tax law to allow a beneficiary rebate in respect of the payment of the Community Development Employment Projects Scheme Participant Supplement. The payment was announced in the 1998-1999 budget and will be subject to the Pay-As-You-Earn and Pay-As-You-Go withholding systems. The amendments will apply to payments made on or after 11 November 1999 and to assessments for the 1999-2000 year of income and all later years of income.

To assist with the implementation of the GST, the Government is providing direct assistance certificates to small and medium enterprises and to community sector bodies when they register for the GST. These certificates will not be subject to tax. This bill amends the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 to ensure that GST direct assistance certificates are exempt from tax that may arise from the receipt or redemption of the certificates.

This bill also gives effect to the announcement by the Minister for Health and Aged Care on 24 May 2000, that high income earners will be subject to the Medicare Levy Surcharge from 1 July 2000 if they purchase private hospital cover on or after 25 May 2000 with excesses greater than $500 for singles or $1,000 for families.
Those with these high excess policies purchased on or before 24 May 2000 are not affected.

This addresses concerns that high income earners have been purchasing inadequate health insurance to avoid the Medicare Levy Surcharge. It will encourage those who can afford to do so to purchase comprehensive hospital insurance and use the private health system when hospital treatment is required.
Full details of the measures in this bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum.
I commend the bill.

quote.para: In just over 50 days, Australia will see the implementation of the most significant tax reform since World War II, including the largest tax cuts in Australia's history. The reform package also includes large increases to family assistance, increases to pensions and all other government benefits, the abolition of wholesale sales tax and the introduction of the GST.

As part of the implementation phase of the GST, the government has embarked upon an extensive information and community education program. Both the Australian Taxation Office and GST Start-Up Assistance Office have played key roles with comprehensive seminar programs, the provision of booklets and fact sheets on the operation of the GST, and several infolines addressing both tax issues and the business skills needed to prepare for tax reform.
The Australian Taxation Office has also issued a large number of rulings on detailed operation of the law in relation to the GST.

As a result of the detailed examination of the law through the rulings process, feedback received from taxpayers on the GST legislation, as well as comments from the New Tax System Advisory Board, several issues have been raised by interested parties including the need for amendments. The government has looked at the issues raised and considers that a number of amendments need to be made to ensure that the legislation remains consistent with the government's original intentions.

The amendments in this bill will apply to the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Act 1999 (the GST Act) and related legislation. They give effect to the measures announced in the Treasurer's Press Release No. 37 of 3 May 2000 as well as some other issues not previously announced.

The measures in this bill cover approximately 30 minor policy issues and 9 technical issues. The majority of the amendments are concessional in nature and will be welcomed by business. In addition, there are a small number of amendments which are regarded as anti-avoidance measures to ensure that aspects of the law operate as intended. The other amendments are technical in nature but are essential to ensure that the legislation operates effectively.
Some of the more important amendments contained in this bill are as follows.

This bill will amend the GST Act to give the Commissioner of Taxation the power to issue guidelines to specify that certain fundraising events undertaken by charities can be treated as input taxed. These fundraising events could include a fete, ball, or other similar event that is separate from and nor forming part of a series of similar events. Events involving the sale of small fundraising items such as badges, flowers and confectionery will be included provided the charitable entity is not in the business of selling such items.

Where the fundraising event does not meet this description, the amendments provide that a charitable entity may make a request to the Commissioner to apply his discretion to treat an activity as input taxed. In applying his discretion, the Commissioner would need to have broad regard to whether the charitable entity is in the business of making such supplies. In addition, the Commissioner must be satisfied that the fundraising is genuine and the proceeds are for the direct benefit of the charity.

This bill amends the GST Act to make the delivery of livestock to a processor a taxable supply. This confirms the government's policy in respect of food to ensure that, as far as practicable, farmers should be in a position to sell their produce subject to GST.

This bill also amends the GST Act to ensure the lease or hire of goods by pre-schools, primary schools and secondary schools to students are GST-free provided the school retains property of those goods. These supplies will be GST-free as long as there is not any transfer, or agreement to transfer ownership of the goods to any student or anyone else at any stage, and the supply must be directly and principally for use by that student in a GST-free education course supplied by the school.
Other measures in this bill relate to:
streamlined processes to let businesses inform insurance companies of their input tax credit status;
allowing more flexible arrangements for accounting for GST for transactions between agents and principals;
clarifying the GST treatment of supplies involving non-residents;
rules for calculating GST;
taking borrowing out of the financial supplies de minimus threshold except for those borrowings that are related to making financial supplies;
applying consistent principles to GST turnover tests to assist pubs and clubs; and
two revenue protection measures to prevent stockpiling of alcoholic beverages.
The amendments in this bill demonstrate that the government is responding to consultations and is prepared to make changes necessary to ensure an effective tax system.
Full details of the amendments in this bill are contained in the explanatory memorandum.
I commend the bill.
