The letter read as follows—

quote.para: March 19, 2000
XXXXXXX
WANTIRNA-VIC 3152
XXXXX (Home)
XXXXX (Bus.)
Mr Kim Beazley MP
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2060
Dear Mr Beazley,

My father, XXXXXs been a resident of the Riverside Nursing Home for five years and he regards it as his home. He is now in the terminal stages of Alzheimers Disease and does not cope very well with change. The move to St Vincents has been distressing not only for the relatives who had minimum consultation from the Aged Care Department but also for the residents themselves. We have been appalled by the decision making process by the Minister and would like to raise the following points for consideration:

. Our family was already traumatized by the recent death of my sister's only child.XXXXX aged 24 was tragically killed in a motorcycle accident at the end of last year. I'm sure you would agree that it is every parent's nightmare to lose a child. To bury your only child is something I find difficult to even begin to contemplate. We, as a family, and particularly my sister, XXXX were already struggling.
. The first we knew of the kerosene baths at Riverside was through the media on 24th February 2000.
. The Minister's department knew of the baths on January 17Th 2000 and yet did nothing for a month.
. We were particularly anxious as our father had two very deep pressure sores and we were understandably concerned of the effect of kerosene on these wounds.

. My father's medical records indicate two entries stating he had a kerosene bath, yet the staff was adamant that he and four other residents were not bathed. I'm not sure which is worse, a kerosene bath or false medical records!
. The department made no attempt to inform my sister XXXX or myself (as my father's administrators) of any of their enquiries into the home thereby heightening our anxiety levels even further.

. The department failed to inform us of their relatives meeting on Sunday 5th March. A family who had received a letter informed us. Apparently only a small number of relatives received notification. At this meeting we provided contact details to the two department representatives.

. At that meeting the two Aged Care Department representatives claimed they had no knowledge of the planned move to St Vincents Hospital the following day despite the plansbeing published in the paper that morning. These two representatives provided no information on the outcome of their investigations thereby heightening the stress levels of all relatives present. The two representatives promised that the decision would be couriered to all relatives early the following day.
. Several relatives had not received their letters by late morning and I received mine late in the day, addressed to Ms Langhorn! .. We once again heard of the decision through the media.

. There was no consultation prior to moving the relatives and it was only after a blockade and a demand for information from the department that Maree Bowman made an appearance. The Minister declined to attend.
. This day proved an extremely distressing one for our family members with our father not being settled until later that night.

. Prior to giving consent to move our father, my sister, Kaylene spoke to the Aged Care department in Canberra and was assured that there was no time limit on the stay at St. Vincents. The following day we were informed that their stay at St Vincents would be for 4 weeks with another 6 weeks at the Mercy hospital, thereby requiring yet another move.

. On that same day we had a junior doctor suggest to us that we stop feeding my father and allow 'nature to take its course'. This suggestion brought back the memories of XXXX death for my sister who was incredibly distressed. This incident is a direct result of the Ministers decision to move the residents to St Vincents Hospital.

. The department organised a. further relatives meeting on 8th March, however once again we were not informed that it was to occur. At that meeting we once again provided contact details to the department representatives.

. As a member of the Relatives Committee at Riverside I downloaded the two Aged Care Standards Agency reports from the internet for April & July 1998 but have found they have since been removed when attempting to find the latest report. Although I have requested a copy of this report I have not received it to date.

. Given the concerns about Riverside were raised in these reports as early as 1998 why did the Minister not conduct spot checks of the home during that time?. The Relatives Committee constantly raised issues of concern.

. Following the publications of excerpts of the most recent report, we have been informed that it was our father who had maggots in his wound. According to the report it was noted on his file that the 'family were not to be informed'. Incidents such as these have meant that our stress levels have continued to remain high. If the Minister had done her job properly, incidents like this one would not have been covered up.'
. The Minister has been negligent in her duty to the most vulnerable members of our society and should resign.
. Whilst the Minister has excused her lack of Ministerial duty by claiming that her department did not inform her., she must take ultimate Ministerial responsibility for her lack of action.
I would appreciate it if you would take up the above matters with the Minister and the Prime Minister and hopefully they will respond, although I suspect they will, bury it instead.
Yours sincerely
Lyn XXXXXX

talk.start.para: —I thank the Senate. The letter is from a family who wrote to Mr Beazley in March. It got referred to me as the opposition spokesperson on aged care. I have spoken with the family. They were happy for me to table the letter. We blacked out the family name, et cetera, just for reasons of privacy. I sought to bring the letter to the parliament's attention because it is the most eloquent and moving description of the human tragedy that surrounded the Riverside Nursing Home and the treatment of the residents there. I thought it was important that I bring it to the parliament's attention because this letter describes better than anything anyone in this place could say the tragedy and the human cost of the closure and evacuation of the residents from Riverside Nursing Home.

speech.para: It provides an important lesson for the parliament and for all members of parliament about how we ought to proceed in a public policy sense with dealing with a nursing home which is not providing good quality care. That is the reason why I sought to have the letter incorporated and brought to the parliament's attention. We could spend an awful lot of money on a commission of inquiry and they would not do as good a job of describing the reasons why we should make sure this is never allowed to happen again. No older Australian or their family should ever have to suffer what the families involved at Riverside had to suffer as a result of the closure and evacuation of that nursing home.

The letter describes—and I encourage senators to read it—the distress of the family, whose father was a long-term resident at Riverside. He was one of those who was bathed in kerosene, despite having very deep pressure sores. Although there was some argument about whether he was one of those bathed, they believe he was bathed. He was also the person who was suffering from a maggot infested wound, which they only found out about much later in the piece. They also found out that the medical reports had been marked in relation to that wound with the words `family not to be informed'. So there was a deliberate attempt to cover up the condition of their father and the suffering that he was going through. They found out all of this information later on, so in addition to the trauma of the evacuation, the closure and the fact that they had to move him to St Vincents, they have had to suffer the revelations about how their father had been treated. Obviously, that has been highly distressing to them.

The other key point that they make is about the absence of consultation with the family: the fact that in a number of important instances they were not informed of what was going on. They feel they were kept in the dark, they were treated very shabbily in terms of being provided information about what was happening to their father, and they have some specific concerns also about what was said to them in a particular incident at St Vincents, when a doctor apparently suggested to them that they stop feeding their father and that they `allow nature to take its course'. So they have had this added trauma of the concern about the treatment of their father.

Their letter is a very well written analysis of the problems, of what occurred at Riverside, and of the way the family and the residents were treated. It is important for us to look at it, because the Aged Care Act provided that the government, when faced with a situation where they had serious concerns about the care of residents—and certainly the minister argues this, had no choice in the end but to close the nursing home and evacuate the residents. The minister claims that was the only public policy option left to her. If that is the case, then clearly we have got to be able to do much better. When we have to act in a serious manner to protect residents, we have got to be able to provide a system that provides much better treatment of the residents than was provided at Riverside.

Most of these residents had dementia and were physically very frail, and some were already in the process of receiving palliative care. They were greatly traumatised by the move. A person of that age and in that condition can find such a move and disruption fatal. The family have obviously had to live with the trauma, the upset, the difficulties of establishing contact in a different environment and of travelling to a new location, and all those sorts of things. They also had to deal with being informed that the care their relative had been given was substandard—and for many of them that was the first time they found out that the department had a view that the standard of care their family member had been receiving was substandard.

The lessons from this are, in my view, that the closure and the evacuation of residents from a nursing home because of poor quality of care ought to be the absolute last resort. The minister said she had no option; my view is that we cannot allow it to happen again. If it is the case that the Aged Care Act provides no better solution when you have a provider who is providing inadequate care, when there is a serious concern about the care provided to residents—and I think that is to be tested—then we have to find a much better response. There is a suggestion I want to explore, which is that we develop a mechanism whereby an administrator is put in place at the direction of the minister and the residents are left in situ in the nursing home. That certainly would provide a much better solution than what we saw at Riverside. Sure, there were some problems with the physical surroundings at Riverside, but most of the issues went to the standard of care—they went to the management, the supervision and the provision of care to those residents—and they could have been addressed by the provision of new administration, by getting one of the reputable aged care providers to take over the administration of the nursing home, at least in the short-term, and to provide proper care to those residents without the disruption of evacuation. It would have also allowed for long-standing relationships with carers and other staff to have been maintained. It would have been a much better result for those residents, for their families and for the staff.

I understand that putting in such a mechanism is not simple, that there are some difficulties. That mechanism has been supported by a number of people. It is a suggestion which I endorse. I think it is one we have to look at very seriously. I think it is not beyond the wit of this parliament to devise a mechanism that allows for that to occur. The Commonwealth pay 80 per cent of the funds that support those nursing homes. We issue the licences, manage the accreditation and certification, and ensure that standards are met. We have the power to ensure that proper care is provided. We ought to make sure that we have a mechanism that ensures, at a time when the minister is convinced that proper care is not being provided, that we have effective sanctions. Most of the sanctions that we have currently are financial sanctions against the provider. What happens when you have a financial sanction against a provider is that they receive less government funds for a period. What do they do when they get less government funds? They reduce the quality of care, they cut the staff hours and they reduce the quality of food because they have less income coming into the nursing home. So most of the sanctions we currently apply against nursing home providers result in, directly or indirectly, them providing even worse care than they provided previously when we raised concerns about their treatment.

I think we must have much more effective sanctions than we have got. I do not think the financial penalties are the answer because they tend to hurt the residents. Certainly I think the appointment of an administrator to put new administration into a nursing home that has provided consistently poor care and which we have serious concern about is the answer. We ought to make sure that we get support to amend the Aged Care Act to make sure that the Riverside situation never occurs again and that we have a much better mechanism for protecting the elderly and allowing them to stay in situ in the nursing home when that is the best option for them.

talk.start.para: —I rise tonight to urge all states and territories to agree with the moratorium on online gambling and to also urge them to take notice of the studies that have been released in recent times on the impact of gambling in this country. Findings from the University of Canberra's National Centre for Social and Economic Modelling have been published in today's Australian. They reveal that in some states the poorest 10 per cent of people in the community are spending more on gambling in total than they spend in total on health and education as a proportion of their income. This compares with the wealthiest 10 per cent of society, who spend a much lower proportion of their money on gambling. The latest of these statistics shows the extent of the vast problem we have with gambling in this country.

speech.para: I have spoken many times about the extent of problem gambling. I have spoken about the figures that were revealed in the Senate's own Netbets inquiry where people from, for example, the Break-Even Western Problem Gambling Service gave evidence. They said that every problem gambler affects directly and indirectly in their families, in their workplaces and in other places another seven to 10 people. The states and territories are ignoring these estimates and we now have before us the next tidal wave of gambling about to hit this country—and that is online gambling. There are predictions that the online gambling industry could reach a worldwide turnover of $100 billion a year. The states and territories are simply ignoring the current problems they are facing with gambling and they are also ignoring this future tidal wave that is about to descend on this country. If the states accept something like online gambling without any controls, they are creating an environment where problem gambling will skyrocket yet again in this country.
I want to speak specifically today about the latest statistics on gambling from the University of Canberra. It was reported on the front page of the Australian today that:

quote.para: The typical poor household out-drinks, out-smokes and out-gambles the top end of town.

speech.para: The study did a breakdown by states of what people spend their money on. The richest 10 per cent of our society were compared, state by state, with the poorest 10 per cent. I am very concerned about the results, as indeed all members of the Senate should be. Take my own state of New South Wales, for example. The top 10 per cent of wealthy households in New South Wales spend, on average, just over one per cent of their weekly income on gambling. By comparison, the lowest income earners spend 6.5 per cent of their weekly income on gambling. In dollar terms, the top 10 per cent of society averages an income per week of $1,800. They spend $31 per week, on average, on gambling. The bottom 10 per cent are the battlers. They have, on average, $503 per week and they spend $33 per week on gambling. It might not seem like a lot of money but, to low income earners, it can mean a massive difference to the quality of life of their family.

What is particularly concerning, if you look at those figures proportionally, is that the lower income earners are spending six times, proportionally, what the higher income earners are spending on gambling. The study backs up the findings of last year's Productivity Commission report and also the Netbets inquiry from the Senate. We have all heard stories of some of Australia's richest people spending hundreds of thousands of dollars on a single bet, whether that be on horse racing or gambling; but these wealthy people are not living from week to week, and they are not worrying about having to put food on the table. The central message is that the poor are spending a much larger proportion of their income on gambling than are people with higher incomes. It is the states and territories that are reaping this money. They are addicted to gambling revenue, as much as the problem gamblers themselves are. With the expansion of online gambling, this could become much worse.

Most recently, the Tasmanian Gaming Commission approved five new licences for online casinos and sports betting. Here in the ACT, two new online gambling licences were issued. This is despite a call from the minister for social security, who is the minister in charge of the Ministerial Council on Gambling, to call a moratorium across the states and territories until we get a proper set of regulations and controls in place. These states and territories have ignored totally the studies and statistics about Australia's chronic gambling problem.

We are ready now to enter another phase of this gambling and what we need, with online gambling coming, is a national framework of regulation to be set up. This is now urgent because the latest studies show that, even in the early stages of online gambling, this form of gambling is being taken up at a very rapid rate. Lasseter's Casino, which has been operating for the last seven months in the Northern Territory, reports that between April and September last year it brought in another 16,000 online players and had a turnover of $18 million. The company predicts that this turnover will now grow at a rate of 75 per cent a month. The same goes for Canbet in the ACT: a turnover of $47 million in 1998-99, and the company expects that in the following year this will double.

But it could get much worse with the new technology coming into play: every household with a television set could, with online gambling, become its own little casino. You do not need digital television to do this, and you do not need a computer; all you need is an ordinary television set with a smart set-top box, which costs about $600, and the screen of your TV then turns into a monitor and you can do sports betting and online gambling in the home. Given the current destructive path that gambling is forging in this country, we should really be the last to roll out the red carpet to online gambling.

There should be a moratorium, as our minister Senator Jocelyn Newman has called for, across all states and territories. During this moratorium, a national regulation framework to protect consumers can be designed and the impact of online gambling can be studied closely, particularly in the Northern Territory where it is has been operating for seven months. Then we should be looking at a decision on where we go with online gambling in the future. It is time for the states and territories to act, to work in unison with the federal government. It is time for the states and territories, who have primary responsibility for gambling, to really start being honest about the extent of problem gambling in this country and to do something about it in an effective way.

Business expenditure on research and development and the R&D Tax Concession were canvassed at the National Innovation Summit held in February this year. (5) The report by the Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE), R&D, Innovation and Competitiveness (Research Report 50, 1993) provides some analysis of the potential effect on business expenditure on research and development as a result of a decline in value of the R&D Tax Concession, with a decrease in the corporate tax rate.

The report discussed the potential effects on the assistance provided by the R&D Tax Concession arising from a reduction in the corporate tax rate. The BIE concluded that, while recognising a basis for an increase in the R&D Tax Concession to maintain the nominal value of the R&D Tax Concession with a lower corporate tax rate, it did not argue strongly in its favour. This conclusion was based on the recognition that a reduction in the corporate tax rate makes all business activities more attractive to industry, including research and development.
The lower corporate tax rate agreed under the Review of Business Taxation effectively offers an extra 6 cents in the dollar of after tax profits, to firms for discretionary investment.

The last decrease in the corporate tax rate occurred in the period 1993/94 to 1994/95 when the rate was reduced from 39% to 33%. During this period business expenditure on research and development increased from $2,862 million in 1992/93 to $3,508 million in 1994/95.

(6) (a) The Department has not undertaken any analysis of the price elasticity of business expenditure on research and development related to the level of the R&D Tax Concession since the report of the BIE noted above. The report discussed the effects on research and development expenditure of alternative tax concession scenarios.

This report indicated that increasing the tax concession may increase research and development expenditure, while reducing the concession may lower research and development expenditure. However, the report also noted that the R&D Tax Concession is just one of many influences on the research and development performance of companies. Other factors include creating a competitive advantage, market opportunities and technological strengths.

The Australian Industry Group survey, Trends in R&D Expenditure in Australian Manufacturing (1999), indicated that 75% of companies cited factors such as trading conditions and profit pressures as more important than the R&D Tax Concession in influencing their decisions on research and development.

(b) Section 8.6 (pp176 to 177) of the BIE report noted above provides full details of the BIE discussion on the “erosion of assistance arising from reductions in the company tax rate”. A copy of this section is available from the Senate Table Office.

talk.start.para: asked the Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 26 April 2000:

quote.para: With reference to the Auditor-General's report no. 23 of 1999-2000, The Management of Tax Debt Collection: Australian Taxation Office, tables 8 and 9 on pages 140 and 141:
(1) Does the Government propose to punish company directors who are debtors to the Australian Taxation Office (ATO) by making them ineligible to be company directors.
(2) What enforcement programs are in place to recover the debt due from company directors who are individual ATO debtors, and whose companies also have active ATO debts.

talker.name: Kemp, Sen Rod
Senator Kemp
talker.role: Assistant Treasurer

talk.start.para: —The following answer is provided to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) The function of deregistering Directors or preventing them from managing corporations is one which is vested in the Australian Securities and Investment Commission (ASIC) under the Corporations Law. The ATO has liaised with ASIC to have companies deregistered.

(2) The ATO frequently uses Director Penalty provisions under Divisions 8 and 9 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. Directors of companies have a duty to ensure that companies meet their tax obligations, or put the companies into liquidation or voluntary administration. If the obligations are not met directors may be given a Directors Penalty notice requiring them within 14 days to either:
. pay the estimates as required;
. enter into a section 222ALA payment agreement;
. appoint an administrator of the company under the Corporations Law; or
. begin to be wound up.
If this requirement is not met directors become personally liable to a penalty equaling the amount not paid. These debts are vigorously pursued by the ATO.

subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2193)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 1 May 2000:

quote.para: (1) Has the Government, or any of its officials, including United Nations officials, been approached regarding the interests of any Northern Territory businessman or member of the Northern Territory Legislative Assembly, present or past, in East Timor in 1999 or 2000; if so: (a) who is involved; (b) what are the details; and (c) what was the response.

talker.name: Hill, Sen Robert
Senator Hill
talker.role: Minister for the Environment and Heritage

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

quote.para: (1) (a) During 1999 and 2000, officials in Australia and in East Timor have been approached by numerous individuals from the Northern Territory on various matters related to their existing and potential business interests in East Timor.

(b) Their queries covered a very wide range of issues related to business operations in East Timor, including questions on entry requirements; queries on social, political and security conditions; assistance on property and tenancy matters; questions on duties and sales tax obligations; transportation queries; queries on meetings with interlocutors in East Timor to discuss specific issues; and a range of consular matters.

(c) In response to these queries, officials have given detailed briefings on the social, political and security situation in East Timor; provided travel advice; provided advice on commercial/regulatory matters in response to specific queries; facilitated meetings and dialogue with interlocutors in East Timor; and provided other assistance reflecting officials' consular responsibilities towards Australian citizens.
The Government is, of course, not in a position to respond to this question on behalf of United Nations officials.
